metadata.synopsis: A US submarine is dispatched to the frozen wastes of the North Pole to recover a Soviet satellite crammed full of strategic snapshots of US bases. The Cold War atmosphere becomes even chillier as the sub, with a Russian expatriate, a British secret agent and an American marine captain on board, is sabotaged en route.

reviews: Buy some popcorn and see the movie.

A fairly tight, exciting, Saturday night adventure story that suddenly goes all muddy in its crises, so that at two crucial points, it is very difficult to know what is going on, or who knows what about it. It doesn't make much difference, though.
An uncharacteristically weak thriller-actioner from the talented director John Sturges.
Hokey but lavishly filmed submarine spy drama.
A conventional Cold War thriller whose flatness keeps it from being as suspenseful as it should be.
Exciting murder-mystery directed by Sturges; Hudson and cast are great.
Sadly, with the exception of 1972's Joe Kidd, Ice Station Zebra marked the end of John Sturges' career as an interesting, innovative director.

If this had been a routine Saturday-afternoon thriller, it might have been fun. But it's been stretched out to roadshow length and loaded down with lots of gimmicks to conceal the thinness of the story.
